Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Carbohydrate Recognition in Type B Carbohydrate Binding Modules
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant cell walls are constructed from a solid polymer of carbohydrate molecules called cellulose. Microbes produce enzymes capable of breaking down the cellulose into individual sugar molecules, which can then be used in chemical processes to make fuel. The enzymes often consist of at least two domains: one responsible for cleaving chemical bonds and one responsible for locating the cellulose surface (Carbohydrate Binding Modules or CBMs). CBMs also help the enzyme differentiate between perfect, crystalline regions and imperfect, non-crystalline regions, yet how the structure of the protein is capable of this distinction remains unknown. Understanding how this happens will enable development of new biotechnology for biofuels production as well as many other applications. This study will train graduate and undergraduate students in the development of realistic protein-carbohydrate models and in advanced thermodynamic calculations. This project will also be integrated into an outreach program intended to promote interest in high performance computing among underrepresented researchers and provide the necessary tools to generate successful results.

NSF-EPSCoR and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division are funding Dr. Christina Payne from the University of Kentucky to determine the mechanisms of carbohydrate recognition in CBMs and the means by which these proteins are capable of binding non-crystalline cellulose more tightly than soluble oligomers. Molecular dynamics simulations and enhanced sampling free energy methods will be used to evaluate the molecular-level origins of oligomeric carbohydrate recognition within and across three families of cellulose-specific, Type B CBMs. Non-crystalline cellulose-binding CBMs will be modeled bound to the insoluble substrate, and alchemical free energy pathways will be used to determine the free energy of binding to non-crystalline cellulose. Molecular dynamics simulations of a tandem CBM construct in solution and in proximity to representative non-crystalline cellulose substrate will be used to relate findings from the individual modules to the tandem construct behavior. Principle component analysis and elastic network modeling will uncover residue correlation and mechanical coupling contributing to cooperative binding and avidity. The outcome of this study will provide an unprecedented level of insight into the complex solid and soluble carbohydrate substrate recognition mechanisms of CBMs, the findings of which hold considerable promise for enhancing biomass conversion technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For nearly 70 years, glycoside hydrolase catalytic domains have been a significant focus of much of the ongoing biomass conversion protein engineering research, with a clearly defined functional role of glycosidic bond cleavage as a straightforward target for improvement. On the other hand, researchers have just begun to recognize the potential of harnessing the carbohydrate recognition capabilities of carbohydrate binding modules (CBMs) for more effective biomass conversion or multitudes of other biotechnological applications. As a result, many fundamental questions remain as to how these proteins recognize carbohydrate substrates, insights of which are critical to continued development of efficient biomass conversion technology.

 

Experimental investigations of CBM protein-carbohydrate recognition mechanisms have had difficulty conclusively addressing many of these fundamental questions. In part, this is a result of the inherent experimental challenges associated with obtaining structural-level insights. The overall goal of this project was to elucidate the molecular-level mechanisms of carbohydrate recognition in CBMs through computational investigation of unexplained phenomena observed in existing experimental literature. We addressed the hypothesis that Type B CBM carbohydrate recognition mechanisms are different for oligomeric and non-crystalline substrates, which may account for the evolutionary occurrence of tandem binding modules. Using molecular simulations and free energy methods, we examined oligomeric and non-crystalline cellulose recognition in three Type B CBM families having specificity for cellulose, providing critical details necessary for advancement in biomass conversion biotechnology. Representative Type B CBMs included: Cellulomonas fimi CBM4-1 and CBM4-2 (CfCBM4-1 and CfCBM4-2); Clostridium cellulovorans CBM17 (CcCBM17); Bacillus sp. 1139 CBM17 (BspCBM17); Bacillus sp. 1139 CBM28 (BspCBM28); and Clostridium josui CBM28 (CjCBM28).

 

Oligomeric carbohydrate recognition within and across CBM families 4, 17, and 28 was evaluated using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and free energy calculations. The results support the hypothesis that C. fimi CBM4s are capable of binding cello-oligomers with the reducing end of the pyranose at either end of the protein binding cleft. Free energy calculations were comparable to experimental isothermal titration calorimetry measurements and go beyond experiment in enabling delineation between conformational populations. MD simulations revealed abundant hydrogen bonding partners exist along the binding cleft, so that regardless of direction, the pyranose ring primary and secondary alcohols are capable of maintaining a hydrogen bond with relevant partners from the interior of the cleft. The ability to bi-directionally bind the ligand appears to extend beyond family 4 CBMs to other carbohydrate-binding proteins bearing the β-sandwich fold, which currently includes 29 additional CBM families. We also elucidated a key difference in cello-oligomer binding across the three evaluated CBM families; the twisted, solvent exposed binding grooves of family 17 and 28 CBMs necessitate tighter substrate binding than the sandwich-like family 4 CBMs.

 

We also defined the mechanisms of non-crystalline carbohydrate recognition by BspCBM28 and CcCBM17. Molecular simulation provided structural and dynamic data for direct comparison to oligomeric modes of carbohydrate recognition, and umbrella sampling MD was used to determine ligand binding free energy. Comparing both modes of protein-carbohydrate interactions with ligand binding free energies, which were within error of experimental estimates of ‘high-’ and ‘low-’ affinity non-crystalline cellulose binding, suggests that the high- and low-affinity binding sites correspond to non-crystalline and oligomeric cellulose binding, respectively. We further examined individual contributions to thermodynamic parameters, revealing that the gain in enthalpy in binding non-crystalline cellulose over oligomers resulted from direct contact of the CBM protein surface with the cellulose substrate. In the long-term, we anticipate the results of this study will advance understanding of how protein-protein interactions and inter-module networking determines additive or cooperative binding in tandem systems and why organisms secret multi-modular enzymes with seemingly redundant CBM domains.

 

Beyond the scientific outcomes, the project provided opportunities for training and professional development of two PhD graduate students and two undergraduate researchers. Research was disseminated to the public through publications and presentations at professional society meetings and universities. The Principal Investigator also actively participated in K-12 STEM outreach, including organizing hands-on workshops at local Girls Scouts events, the Expanding Your Horizons girls STEM conference, and Engineering-Day events.
